construction: The schematic shows a push-pull amplifier composed of two common collector (CC) single-transistor amps.  Nodes for the input signal, resistors and other parameters have been given to you.  Assume that the capacitors act as short circuits for the input signal.  Create a model of the AC behavior of the circuit and examine the voltage across the load.  Try modifying the transistor parameters.  Do you see why they have to have matching parameters?
execution: The schematic and model show a push-pull amplifier composed of two common collector (CC) single-transistor amps. Assume that the capacitors act as short circuits for the input signal.
incremental: The schematic shows a push-pull amplifier composed of two common collector (CC) single-transistor amps.  Nodes for the input signal, resistors and other parameters have been given to you.  Assume that the capacitors act as short circuits for the input signal.  Create a model of the AC behavior of the circuit and examine the voltage across the load.  Try modifying the transistor parameters.  Do you see why they have to have matching parameters?

givenModelNodes.name: AC Vb of Q1
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of base voltage of Q1
givenModelNodes.explanation: Capacitor C1 just passes the input signal voltage along.

givenModelNodes.name: AC of Ib into Q1
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of the base current into Q1
givenModelNodes.explanation: Assuming Q1 is biased so that the DC base voltage is right at the knee voltage of the BE junction, when the signal is positive, then a current flows into the base and its magnitude is determined by the resistance of the BE junction and Ohm's law.  When the signal is negative, then the BE junction is reverse biased, so no current flows.  One can use the max(...) function to implement this calculation.

givenModelNodes.name: R of BE junction of Q1
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of the BE junction of Q1

givenModelNodes.name: AC of Ic into Q1
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of current into collector of Q1

givenModelNodes.name: AC of Vb of Q2
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of base voltage of Q2
givenModelNodes.explanation: C2 just passes the input signal voltage along.

givenModelNodes.name: AC of Ib into Q2
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of current into base of Q2
givenModelNodes.explanation: Assuming Q2 is properly biased, then when the base voltage swings negative, the BE junction becomes forward biased and a current flows. The size of the current is determined by the resistance of the BE junction and Ohm's law.  When the base voltage swings positive, the BE junction becomes reverse biased, and no current flows.  You can use the min(...) function to implement this calculation.

givenModelNodes.name: R of BE junction of Q2
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of BE junction of Q2

givenModelNodes.name: AC of Ic into Q2
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of current into Q2's collector

givenModelNodes.name: AC of current into RL
givenModelNodes.description: AC of current into left terminal of RL

givenModelNodes.name: AC of Ie out of Q1
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of current out of Q1 emitter

givenModelNodes.name: AC of Ie out of Q2
givenModelNodes.description: AC of current out of Q2 emitter

givenModelNodes.name: AC V across RL
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of V across load resistor

schemas.name: CC Push Pull Amplifier AC Behavior
